etymology.description: 一(一) (yī, "one; single") denotes unity or a singular entity, while 切(切) (qiè, "all; every") expands this to encompass all, forming 'everything'.
etymology.interpretation: 一切(一切) (yīqiè, "everything") combines 一(一) (yī, "one") with 切(切) (qiè, "all") to express the totality of existence or all aspects of a situation or environment. The term is often used to denote comprehensive inclusion, reflecting the idea that all things are considered as one.

examples.chinese: 他放弃一切(他放棄一切)。
她努力工作(她努力工作)，追求一切梦想(追求一切夢想)。
examples.pinyin: Tā nǔlì gōngzuò, zhuīqiú yīqiè mèngxiǎng.
examples.english: She works hard, pursuing all her dreams.

examples.chinese: 一切皆有可能(一切皆有可能)。
